p: Due to the high prevalence in blood donors, transmission of HEV by blood transfusion has been observed [ 4, 26, 32, 33, 44– 47], but not all patients receiving HEV-positive blood got infected [ 33, 44, 46]. The infectivity of HEV-contaminated components for transfusion was in one study 50% [ 48] and seems to depend upon the virus load [ 33, 46]. HEV transmission depends not only on the virus load, but also on the blood component given and on the presence of antibodies in the preparation [ 33]. Overall, donations containing antibody were less likely to transmit. HEV transmission was also associated with organ transplantation, but only in single cases [ 49– 51]. The prevalence of persistent HEV infection in patients with solid organ transplantation in Western Europe varies between 0.7 and 3.2% [ 52]. The different observed incidences strongly depend on the respective antibody test applied in the respective study.
